item.title: How Should Africa Respond to Trump’s Tariffs?
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs are hitting African exporters hard, jeopardizing growth and regional stability. To avoid being sidelined in a fragmented global trading landscape, African governments must bargain collectively to negotiate deals with the US and strengthen ties with other emerging powers.

item.title: Inflationary Tales
item.description: The inflationary surge of the 1970s has long served as a cautionary tale, and that episode has shaped how central banks have carried out their mandates ever since. Two recent books revisit the standard narrative about that period in light of the 2021–23 inflation, offering sharply contrasting lessons for the future.

item.title: Is Trump a State Capitalist?
item.description: While US President Donald Trump has embraced some elements of the free-market doctrine that dominated economic policymaking over the last century, he has also pursued an unprecedented level of state intervention in the US economy. With Trump’s “pay-to-play” approach to economic management seemingly combining the worst of both worlds, we asked PS commentators how it might transform American capitalism.

item.title: The Twilight of Pax Americana
item.description: If Donald Trump continues to wield the threat of higher tariffs, he might be able to claim a few more “victories,” in the form of exploitative trade deals with longtime US allies and partners. But the costs of ignoring basic economic realities will be high, and US global leadership may never recover.

item.title: Globalization Is Dead, but Planetarization Has Yet to Be Born
item.description: Future historians (if there are any) will wonder why, in the mid-2020s, humans poured unprecedented resources into preparing to fight each other, while neglecting collective action against obvious planetary threats. If there is to be any hope of survival, a new mindset must take hold.

item.title: Israel’s Doha Strike Has Destroyed American Credibility
item.description: After decades of enjoying impunity for its violations of international law and norms, Israel no longer even hesitates to do whatever it wants. Aside from the individual victims of the attack on Hamas negotiators in Qatar, the main casualty of Israel’s escalation is US credibility.

item.title: Is a French Sovereign-Debt Crisis Looming?
item.description: It is highly likely that the European Central Bank will have to intervene to prop up France's economy. But this lending will almost certainly have conditions attached, which the French political class will probably not accept until they are staring down the barrel of a government-bond-market collapse.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Will Widen the North-South Divide
item.description: An analysis of US President Donald Trump's "reciprocal" tariffs reveals a stark conclusion: the lower a country’s income, the higher the tariff burden it is likely to bear. In this sense, the tariffs almost seem to be deliberately designed to impede development and exacerbate global inequalities.

item.title: Fighting Poverty Must Not Stop
item.description: Reducing poverty fuels growth, bolsters resilience, and fosters stability, making it essential to long-term development. Even amid economic slowdowns and strained public budgets, governments must double down on human capital and infrastructure investments through well-designed, cost-effective strategies.

item.title: Science Isn’t a Luxury for Developing Countries
item.description: From the COVID-19 pandemic to intensifying climate shocks, a series of crises has exposed the risks of depending on wealthy countries to deliver scientific and technological solutions. If developing economies are to respond effectively to crises and take control of their development, they must build their own research ecosystems.

item.title: For Whom the Ukrainian Bell Tolls
item.description: With Vladimir Putin apparently willing to shrug off any number of losses, one must assume that Russia will be able to sustain a grinding war of attrition for as long as it takes to deplete Ukraine’s ranks. That is why supporting Ukraine now requires finding ways to get more foreign volunteers to join the fight.

item.title: A New Economics for Neglected Places
item.description: In rich and poor countries alike, when left-behind regions are hit by an adverse shock, they will spiral down unless the shock is mitigated by supportive and timely finance guided by local contextual knowledge. That is the clear lesson from successful cases of economic renewal over the past half-century.

item.title: Global Trade Is Winning Trump’s War On It
item.description: Since returning to the White House, Donald Trump has repeatedly introduced, paused, reversed, and hiked tariffs, often to unprecedented levels, raising fears about the future of the global trading system. But the average effective tariff rate that the US has applied remains much lower than Trump's pronouncements would suggest.

item.title: China’s “Trump” Card
item.description: Faced with an unreliable administration in the United States, many countries are now seeking alternatives to reduce their long-term exposure to US policymaking. China has taken note and is billing itself as a steady hand that remains committed to multilateralism, long-term deals, and “non-interference.”

item.title: Why Are Financial Markets Shrugging at Trump’s War on the Fed?
item.description: Few laws of economics are better established than the proposition that central banks independent from politics do a better job of implementing monetary policy. So why are financial markets responding to Donald Trump's attacks on the US Federal Reserve so calmly?

item.title: France’s Manufactured Debt and Government Drama
item.description: French Prime Minister François Bayrou’s government collapsed following a parliamentary confidence vote, and it has only itself to blame. In fact, there is good reason to think that citizens are overwhelmingly rejecting the government's budget precisely because they have effectively been told that they cannot.

item.title: The US Tightens the Dollar’s Death Grip on Brazilian Democracy
item.description: By imposing sanctions on Brazilian Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes, US President Donald Trump’s administration has launched an unprecedented assault on Brazil’s judicial independence. The move also underscores how the dollar’s global primacy undermines other countries’ sovereignty.

item.title: Who Will Model Democracy Now?
item.description: Not so long ago, people around the world could look to Europe and America to see that economic growth, social justice, and political freedom are not only compatible but mutually reinforcing. While authoritarianism is on the rise in both places, one can find democratic role models elsewhere.

item.title: Why Is Europe So Wimpy?
item.description: With Donald Trump's rogue America threatening from one side, Vladimir Putin's Russia from the other, and China becoming increasingly authoritarian, Europeans can no longer afford their leaders’ passivity. And democrats everywhere are also waiting for the world's only remaining good guy to step up.

item.title: Indonesian Democracy on the Brink
item.description: The protests currently sweeping Indonesia are not fleeting outbursts, but rather the culmination of long-suppressed grievances over abuses of power and the erosion of constitutional norms. To address this widespread discontent, President Prabowo Subianto must focus on four priorities.
